title: How Parliament Actually Works — The Complete Beginner's Guide
summary: Every law affecting your life went through this process. Understanding Parliament gives you power to participate in democracy.

children.text: Every law affecting your life — tax, health, housing, crime — went through the process described below. Understanding how it works gives you power to participate.
Elected by you every 3 years. Their jobs: Make laws, Hold the Government to account, Represent your interests.
= The party (or coalition) with 61+ seats. They run the country.
= Everyone else. Their job is to question, challenge, and offer alternatives.
= The referee. An MP (usually from Government benches) who keeps order.
Idea → Bill Draft → First Reading → Select Committee → Second Reading → Committee of Whole House → Third Reading → Royal Assent → LAW
Usually a minister says 'we need to fix X' or an ordinary MP proposes a change (called a Member's Bill).
Lawyers draft the actual legal text. Published publicly so anyone can read it.
Parliament debates the principle — do we want this at all? Vote: 50% to continue. Most bills pass this stage.
Bill goes to a small group of MPs (usually cross-party). Public can submit opinions — this is your chance to be heard. Committee can suggest changes. This is where most changes happen.
Parliament debates the details. More changes possible.
Step 6: Committee of the Whole House
Every MP can suggest tweaks. Line-by-line examination.
Governor-General signs it (formality). Becomes law (now called an Act).
Vote (every 3 years), Submit to Select Committees, Email/call your MP, Watch Question Time, Rally others on issues you care about.
The reality: Most day-to-day decisions happen in Cabinet, not Parliament. But Parliament is where laws get locked in — or stopped. Select Committees actually read public submissions.

keyPoints: Parliament = 120 MPs, Government needs 61+ seats to govern
Bills become laws through 8 steps including Select Committees
Select Committees accept public submissions — your main point of power
Question Time is political theatre but sometimes revealing
